Package infodynamics.measures.continuous

Interface TransferEntropyCalculator

  • All Superinterfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlain, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlainIterators, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelSeparate, TransferEntropyCalculatorKraskov, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateSingleObservationsKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo, TransferEntropyCalculatorSymbolic, TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo, TransferEntropyCommon
    public interface TransferEntropyCalculator
extends ChannelCalculator

    Interface for implementations of the transfer entropy (TE), which may be applied to univariate continuous time-series data. That is, it is applied to double[] data, indexed by time. See Schreiber below for the definition of transfer entropy, and Lizier et al. for the definition of local transfer entropy. Specifically, this class implements the pairwise or apparent transfer entropy; i.e. we compute the transfer that appears to come from a single source variable, without examining any other potential sources (see Lizier et al, PRE, 2008).

    Usage of the child classes implementing this interface is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator;
    2. Set properties using setProperty(String, String) which may now include properties describing the source and destination embedding;
    3. Initialise the calculator using InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.initialise() or initialise(int);
    4. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using:
      • ChannelCalculator.setObservations(double[], double[]) or ChannelCalculator.setObservations(double[], double[], boolean[], boolean[]) for calculations based on single time-series, OR
      • The following sequence:
        1. ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(), then
        2. One or more calls to ChannelCalculator.addObservations(double[], double[]) or ChannelCalculator.addObservations(double[], double[], int, int), then
        3. ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations();
    5. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average TE: InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • the local TE values for these samples: computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
      • local TE values for a specific set of samples: ChannelCalculator.computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[], double[])
      • the distribution of TE values under the null hypothesis of no relationship between source and destination values: EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance(int) or EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance(int[][]).
    6. Return to step 2 or 3 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

    • Method Detail

      • initialise

        void initialise​(int k)
         throws java.lang.Exception
        Initialise the calculator for re-use with new observations. A new history length k can be supplied here; all other parameters remain unchanged.
        Parameters:
        k - destination history embedding length to be considered.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setProperty

        void setProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName,
                 java.lang.String propertyValue)
          throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets properties for the TE calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • K_PROP_NAME -- destination history embedding length k (default value 1)
        • K_TAU_PROP_NAME -- embedding delay for the destination past history vector (default value 1)
        • L_PROP_NAME -- embedding length for the source past history vector (default value 1)
        • L_TAU_PROP_NAME -- embedding delay for the source past history vector (default value 1)
        • DELAY_PROP_NAME -- source-destination delay (default value is 1)

        Note: further properties may be defined by child classes.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if there is a problem with the supplied value, or if the property is recognised but unsupported (eg some calculators do not support all of the embedding properties).

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon

        Computes the local values of the implemented channel measure, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local TE values. If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then this time-series will have zero entries until the source and destination embedding vectors are defined.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
